awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Development of an AI PCB Prototyping Service called FlashPCB
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this SBIR Phase I project is to create an artificial intelligence-powered printed circuit board assembly (PCBA) service that facilitates innovation and economic growth in the United States. Prototyping PCBAs is a key element in the innovation process for all electronics from consumer goods to medical devices, but current PCBA prototyping services are limited by manual steps and supply chain shortages. The artificial intelligence innovation of this project will save the customers time through strategic automation, shortening innovation timelines, and bringing new products to market faster. Currently, China and other Asian countries are still dominating the PCBA market share, serving many customers from the United States. There is an opportunity to provide high-quality, cost-competitive manufacturing in the United States to better serve the market and meet the rising demand for PCBAs. Additionally, investment in domestic manufacturing will strengthen electronic manufacturing capabilities, reduce dependence on foreign markets, and protect intellectual property. 

The technical innovation of this project is the development of two artificial intelligence algorithms that work together to determine the optimal selection of components to be mounted on a customer’s printed circuit board. The first algorithm reads the design file and identifies the properties of the components that the user has specified for their design. The second algorithm takes these properties as its input and selects in stock parts for the components in the design which will then be mounted onto the printed circuit board. This is a cost and time saving innovation that uses state of the art artificial intelligence algorithms and encodes electrical engineering principles. The key objectives for this project are to understand the types and combinations of components that our customers are likely to use in their designs, to define and test the algorithm for component property identification, and to define and test the algorithm which will choose the optimal components used for the manufacture of PCBAs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The outcome of this SBIR Phase I project is the creation of an artificial intelligence-powered printed circuit board assembly (PCBA) service that facilitates innovation and economic growth in the United States. Prototyping PCBAs is a key element in the innovation process for all electronics from consumer goods to medical devices, but many current PCBA prototyping services are limited by manual steps and supply chain shortages. The artificial intelligence innovation of this project saves customers? time through the automated component selection, eliminating bottlenecks from component shortages. This strategic automation will shorten innovation timelines and bring new products to market faster. Currently, China and other Asian countries are still dominating the PCBA market share, serving many customers from the United States. There is an opportunity to provide high-quality, cost-competitive rapid manufacturing in the United States to better serve the market and meet the rising demand for PCBAs. Additionally, investment in domestic manufacturing will strengthen electronic manufacturing capabilities, reduce dependence on foreign markets, and protect intellectual property.

 

The first outcome was the development of two artificial intelligence algorithms that work together to determine the optimal selection of components to be mounted on a customer?s printed circuit board. PCBA manufacturing, broadly, is a two step process. The first step is manufacturing the blank printed circuit board (PCB). The second step is soldering components onto the PCB. This second step is called assembly. The technical innovation of this project addresses the inefficiencies of preparing the PCB design for assembly, a process that includes creating a quote, sourcing the components, checking that the board is manufacturable, and eventually soldering the components onto the board. The first algorithm employs a neural network to identify the electrical properties associated with each component in a PCB design. Each component in a PCB design has a text entry associated with it in which the PCB designer has described that component. This text entry, along with the physical properties of the component in the design, are generally enough information to find a suitable component for the design. This first algorithm outputs a list of properties specified by the free text entry. The second algorithm takes these properties as its input and selects in stock parts for the components in the design which will then be mounted onto the printed circuit board. This is a cost and time saving innovation that uses state of the art artificial intelligence algorithms and encodes electrical engineering principles.

 

The second outcome of this project is the creation of the FlashPCB component library. This is a design library which we have published and is free to use that covers all of the components that are still in active production used in open source reference designs published on two popular sites, Adafruit and SparkFun. The library was created as a tool for our customers to use in their design and as an aid to our system in determining the manufacturability of our customers? designs. The library encodes a rich depth of information useful to PCB designers and manufacturers alike.

 

The final outcome of this project is a prototype of the FlashPCB service that is open to the public. We are able to produce fully assembled boards for Eagle and KiCad users. This service gives us the ability to test our manufacturing process, increase the number of supported components, grow the FlashPCB library based on customer demand and further explore our product market fit. This service currently offers 10 day lead times for PCBAs and uses our AI algorithms for component selection for footprints in the FlashPCB library. This service is available at flashpcb.com.

 

The FlashPCB service has the capacity for broad impacts on the innovation and economic competitiveness of the United States. Prototyping PCBAs is a key element in the innovation process for any electronics from consumer goods to medical devices. The PCB prototyping market has barriers, including long lead times and high costs which can limit the number of iterations of a design. Our service addresses each barrier, creating a domestic, economical prototyping service that delivers high quality boards and enables faster and more frequent iteration on designs. This will increase economic competitiveness and foster innovation in the United States.

 


Last Modified: 10/19/2023
Modified by: Thomas M Castner
